title: 110_s1914
content: The Act titled "Nuclear Policy and Posture Review Act of 2007" is referred to as the short title. It includes a revised nuclear policy review and nuclear posture review. The President is required to conduct a nuclear policy review to assess the role of nuclear weapons in US security policy. The review will involve key officials and address the current global security environment and establish objectives for US nuclear weapons policy. The President is conducting a nuclear policy review to assess the role of nuclear weapons in US security policy, considering the contributions of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and exploring the relationship between US nuclear policy and nonproliferation objectives. The President is conducting a nuclear policy review to assess the role of nuclear weapons in US security policy, considering the contributions of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and exploring the relationship between US nuclear policy and nonproliferation objectives. The Treaty Between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics on the Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms, signed at Moscow July 31, 1991 (commonly referred to as the ``START I Treaty''), and the Treaty Between the United States of America and the Russian Federation on Strategic Offensive Reductions, done at Moscow May 24, 2002 (commonly referred to as the ``Moscow Treaty''), in achieving the national security and nonproliferation goals of the United States and in implementing United States military strategy, and describe the elements of a recommended successor treaty, including verification provisions; and provide policy guidance and make. The Secretary of Defense conducts a comprehensive review of the US nuclear posture after the nuclear policy review, collaborating with other key officials. The review aims to clarify US nuclear deterrence policy and strategy. Outside experts contribute to the policy review, which may include public meetings to consider various viewpoints. The nuclear posture review, conducted by the Secretary of Defense, involves key officials like the Director of National Intelligence and the National Security Advisor. It includes elements such as the role of nuclear forces in US military strategy, policy requirements for a credible nuclear deterrence posture, and the targeting strategy to implement guidance from the nuclear policy review. The nuclear posture review includes determining the levels and composition of nuclear delivery systems, the nuclear weapons complex, and the nuclear weapons stockpile needed for implementing US national and military strategy. Plans for removing, replacing, or modifying existing systems, consolidating, modernizing, or modifying the complex, and replacing or modifying warheads are also considered. The President is required to submit reports to Congress on the results of the nuclear policy review and the nuclear posture review, with the latter due by March 1, 2010. The reports must be in unclassified form but may contain a classified annex. Congress also expresses its views on the use of the Nuclear Posture Review. The nuclear policy review conducted under subsection (a) should be used as the basis for future strategic arms control objectives and negotiating positions of the United States. No funds may be appropriated for the Reliable Replacement Warhead Program for fiscal years 2008, 2009, or 2010 until the required reports have been submitted to Congress.
